title: Portuguese Loanwords in English
description: From albino to marmalade, explore the surprising Portuguese roots of many English words shaped by global exploration!

questions.question: The word 'albino' comes from the Portuguese 'albino.' What Latin root does it derive from?
Which English word for a type of orange preserve comes from the Portuguese 'marmelo' (quince)?
The word 'fetish' entered English from the Portuguese 'feitico.' What did 'feitico' originally mean?
Which English word for a type of social caste system came through Portuguese contact with India?
The word 'cobra' comes from the Portuguese 'cobra de capello.' What does this phrase mean?
Which English word for a type of veranda or covered walkway comes from the Portuguese 'varanda'?
The word 'molasses' comes from the Portuguese 'melaco.' What is 'melaco' derived from?
Which English word for a type of wooden sailing vessel used in exploration comes from Portuguese?
The word 'pagoda' entered English from Portuguese. What type of structure is a pagoda?
options: A tiered tower associated with Buddhist temples

questions.question: Which word for a test of gold purity came through Portuguese from the Arabic 'toque'?
The word 'junk' (a type of sailing ship) entered English through Portuguese from Malay. Where were these ships commonly used?
options: East Asian and Southeast Asian waters

questions.question: Which English word for a type of umbrella-like canopy derives from Portuguese explorers' accounts?
The word 'banana' entered English through Portuguese or Spanish. Portuguese traders encountered bananas primarily where?
Which English word meaning 'a self-governing state or community' comes from the Portuguese 'comando'?
The word 'tempura' (battered fried food) entered Japanese from the Portuguese 'tempero.' What did 'tempero' mean?
